attributes.Title: ST-Grant Writing
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
697W
UMass Amherst
This course is designed to help students gain practical experience in writing and revising grant proposals.  The course is intended particularly for students planning to apply for NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grants, but may be useful for students applying for other research grants as well.  Students will each write an independent grant proposal that will be peer-reviewed by a mock panel composed of student and faculty reviewers. A revised version will be due at the end of the semester that addresses panel comments. Lectures will provide information and advice regarding grantsmanship, funding opportunities, and application procedures. Students applying for DDIGs will receive panel comments before the grant deadline.
Open to Graduate ORG&EVBI students.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
38330

attributes.Title: ST-Science Communication
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
697K
UMass Amherst
This course is designed to give graduate students in the life sciences experience in communicating science to audiences outside their academic field. Lectures will provide opportunities for science communication and effective ways of engaging non-scientific audiences. Students will give brief oral popular-science presentations, participate in discussions about science communication, write and peer-review other students' popular science articles, and work in groups to propose potential new outreach programs.
Open to graduate students in Molecular & Cellular Biology, Organismic & Evolutionary Biology, Neuroscience & Behavior, and Plant Biology.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
68353

attributes.Title: OEB Evolution Core Course
attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
790A
UMass Amherst
Foundation course required for all OEB graduate students along with the OEB Ecology Core Course.  Graduate level topics covering key conceptual issues in evolutionary biology, including population genetics, molecular evolution, speciation, and phylogenetics.  Laboratory sessions include problem sets, data manipulation and computer exercises to provide practice with quantitative methods in evolutionary biology.
Open to Graduate students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
78192
